R0GYWAenMV0dGU5TkekxaQ.review_text: I come to the Brickhouse Cafe every now and then before making my way over to AT&T Park for a Giants game. On Saturday afternoon I stopped by here for some eats and cheap happy hour specials. If you go there between 4 p.m. - 6 p.m. (I believe it is), drinks are $1 off and appetizers are $2 off. This is what we got off the menu:  - Jalapeño poppers w/ basil ranch sauce: These were actually incredibly satisfying. They were seasoned well and the basil ranch sauce it was served with was really good -- way more fun than just your typical ranch sauce.   - Fish tacos: I wish I could write a review about this. But after ordering the server came back and told me they were out of fish....at only 4:30 p.m. Thought it was worth mentioning.   - Brichouse mixed green salad: This was actually quite delicious and my favorite of all of the items we orded. The raspberry vinagrette was incredibly tasty and the pear added a nice touch.   - Fried calamari: EEK! This calamari was not the business. So over cooked and really difficult to eat. It was so chewy and not tender at all. I won't be ordering this again when I return.  - Bloody Mary (2): The first one was a little off -- too much horseradish. But we asked the bar tender to tone it down on the second one and it was a much better turn out.  - Mamosa (2): A great poor and incredibly satisfying on a sunny san francisco day.  Total bill for 2 (large) appetizers, 1 (large) entree salad, and 4 drinks from the bar = $36.  When I got the bill I was shocked! So much food and a decent amount of drinks for so little money. Definitely a great spot for happy hour :)

Vjk5FemZ5rwJuJ7Sznd3fA.review_text: On the way to a show at 330 Ritch, decided to stop off here for dinner - it was just right for the occasion. We wanted a quick-ish bite of not too pricey good food. I can't think of too much else that's open at night in SOMA that fits these requirements.  Lots of burger and beer choices. I had the roast chicken, which was a little greasy, but suit me just fine.  Plus, we had a round of $2 PBR - can't complain there. With a jazz duo playing in the background, and cool little antique nick nacks all over the restaurant, I will likely be back, should i need something low key in SOMA again.

TZFJqredSnAVI2KBXb1_dg.review_text: Good first experience here in a place within two blocks of home.  Lunch is ordered at the register and although I was told to listen for my number, they gave me full table service. The burger and fries were perfect. Dinner is full service, they say. Menu looks great, changes often, and the staff was super friendly. I'll be back!

LzkmZrSptwo4RljYN2w7Yw.review_text: Well, as always, Brickhouse is a big winner for me and my gal.  We love going there for lunch.  Thinking about their burgers just makes my mouth water!!!  Great staff, and I love the decor.  I wanna ride the tricyle hanging from the ceiling.

RUO2JER7Y5cvqd_nC1XbKg.review_text: The Mexican is the best burger I've ever had. The live music was stellar. The drinks are creative and good. Garlic fries 5 stars. Mind blowing malt milkshakes. Would recommend to anyone!

b19Q2ZB901CpGNAt2016CQ.review_text: Garlic fries amazing- Beet salad pretty good, burger good but gluten free bun not so good, tomato soup good and there is NOT gluten free beer! Salmon pretty good.... appreciate wild salmon and grass fed beef options. please get gluten free beer, better gf buns, and organic cheese?

0GyvKAcRFZMOGEZSZ_jZvg.review_text: What a great comfy atmosphere, BEST Bloody Mary's and the food is delicious. Can't go wrong here. Brickyard Bennies (with pulled pork) is to die for, so is the crab melt. YUM!!! Let's not forget the amazing customer service :-)

C6kbqgKOzgyhRHgdo7iZZA.review_text: We ate dinner here twice over this last Labor Day holiday week. Once was planned, the second time wasn't - they were the only decent restaurant in the neighborhood open on the holiday. We were also able to get in without a reservation. Dining spontaneity doesn't always pay off so well.  Their food was consistently very good and they have a small but decent wine list. I thought the service was pretty good too. The one night they had some live music, which was a little loud in the small space, but enjoyable and an unexpected treat.  We were told their menu is seasonal too, so we'll definitely be back.

toggiW-XWTWLUkqbf-ze_g.review_text: Great brunch place with good prices and lots of variety on the menu. Good for groups, they have awesome $3 mimosas and the French Toast is awesome.

GlkohnSlQtUu29FNsbF1bQ.review_text: $2.00 PBR my husband is in heaven, plus they have Guinness for me! Good bar food... EXCELLENT Buffalo Wings.  The first time we went (Halloween night) we had really good serves.  The second time we went (in February) OK serves.  Last week, Down right BAD service.  I think we will try it one more time to see.  BUT who cares if they have $2.00 PBR if you can't get one...

fyeO1diymWTO6EteJYWM0w.review_text: I've been here twice now. The first time was great- we came on a weeknight for dinner, and thoroughly enjoyed the food and beer. Come to think of it, I think we'd had many drinks that night, which may have skewed our perceptions. Oops.   With that experience in mind, we came back for late lunch on a Saturday (maybe 3:00ish). We had issues with the service and the food this second time around, so really, there were no redeeming qualities.   The place was actually pretty crowded, and I could tell right away that they were understaffed. Regardless, they quickly sat us at an open table without so much as a word (no "how are you?" or mention of how busy they were...nothing).   That initial exchange was a sign of things to come. We started reviewing our menu and eventually decided on what we wanted-- which takes a significant amount of time for my indecisive bf and I. As we're narrowing down our options, I realize that we haven't even heard from our waiter yet. 10 minutes later, he finally swings by and we order everything all at once, since who knows when we'll see him again!  From there, we don't see him for another hour or so. Someone else brings out our drinks and food, and we seriously have to hunt people down for refills and condiments. The food itself was eh. I got the chicken-brie sandwich, which was dry and and overdone. The bf got the burger, which was kinda soggy and fell apart. Ick.   I used to wait tables, so I have empathy for when servers are jammed, but seriously, just tell us and come up with a back up plan. Our waiter hardly said two words to us and never apologized for the lack of service. Not only that, but we had a hard time getting ANYONE to help us- bus boys, other servers, bartenders. It was really aggravating. I see little reason to come back again.

f0fCol8JC6jLIuCnzl8pCg.review_text: Great food, reasonably priced, attentive service.  One of the best burgers in SF!

NnzhHARuS94VzVQ-WqIdxw.review_text: PROs: +Good menu - Sesame Salad was delicious and big enough for leftovers. +Good beer. +Friendly bartender and waitstaff.  CONs: -We need a longer happy hour!!!

YKu33NNXHgghlqiWl3Z0Cw.review_text: I've been to Brickhouse a couple of times already and I'm really not sure why. There's nothing incredibly appealing or uniquely special about this place but for some reason I find myself wanting to come back. Maybe it's the fact that it's a few blocks away from my apartment. Or maybe it's because it's a cool spot that isn't trying to do too much. There are no themes, no arrogant servers, no complicated menus: just good food, plenty of space, and a satisfying Happy Hour menu.  The food here is standard American fare. The burgers, sandwiches, and salads all come in hearty portions, are moderately priced, and most importantly: taste pretty damn good. The Grilled Chicken and Brie Sandwich was only $9 and tasted great. The melted cheese, juicy chicken, crisp apples, and fluffy foccaccia bread made for a kick-ass sandwich that I'd definitely order again. The calamari and garlic fries are also pretty good--well-seasoned and not overly greasy. There is also a pretty extensive beer menu (which is great considering happy hour starts early at 4:30 and lasts until 6:30pm!). Finally, brunch at Brickhouse is equally delicious. The vanilla bean French toast is incredible - fluffy, moist, and with the perfect hint of vanilla flavor. Definitely a must-try for all you French toast lovers!  Brickhouse gets bonus points for super friendly service, plenty of seating, and live jazz music Fridays-Sundays. Although it's certainly not a spot that is special enough to merit more than a 15-minute commute, if you live in South of Market, it's definitely worth the trek.

czJjUvuzfil0agvji1C6qA.review_text: This review is for takeout.  We tried their ribs and fish and chips.  The ribs were tasty - tender and fell off the bone easily.  The fish and chips were fine, but nothing spectacular.  I felt like the meal was exceptionally heavy, especially their sides.  But, I will probably come here again, maybe to actually eat as it seemed to have a fun, relaxed vibe inside.

6XCZoufB_S-sY6vsxMGd8Q.review_text: They were so close in getting a 1 star.  We came here at around 8pm last night and the ambiance is a cool and cozy place.  They have a full bar and their menu are priced reasonably.  Burgers and other foods will run you anywhere from 8 to 20 dollars.  We arrived with 8ppl and were immediately seated.  We ordered our drinks.  2 cosmos, 2 grey goose and soda, and a glass of house red.  30 minutes later we get 2 cosmos.  10 minutes later we sent one of our friends to pick up the rest of the drinks.  Yes..........it took 40 minutes to get our drinks.  We practically had to beg the waitress to take our orders because some of us had a show to catch.  She quickly took our orders and we were thinking that it would probably take another 40 minutes for our food.  Well........it didn't take 40 minutes and within 15 minutes we got all of our food.  This is when the one star review changed into a 3 star.  This was the only saving grace.  The food was 4 stars.  We ordered the mexican, no not our busboy but the burger, chicken ceasar salad, the salmon salad, onion rings, and garlic fries.  Everything was decent and above average.  Nothing spectacular but a solid restaurant serving great burgers, soups, and salads.  If the service was a little bit quicker this would be a 4 star restaurant for sure.  Might come here for lunch.  I heard it was better during that time.  Will update it soon hopefully.  My friend Sandy L works right around the corner, so it might be very soon.

s4O8baEyijx68SOrz668rg.review_text: No complaints here. Wait staff was a bit slow but looked like they were short-handed so I didn't mind. The lady we had was extremely friendly.  The bluesy bacon cheese burger was indeed bluesy - and by that I don't mean like the shape of male testicles after a night of dry hump but no home run (or even 3rd base). This angus beef burger had a very thick layer of crumbled blue cheese - if you're a fan of blue cheese (me like lots of blue cheese), this sandwich is right up your alley.  Beer battered onion rings were fantastic, and garlic fries basically killed any post-meal lip locking plans with the girlfriend but that's life.  I would go back in a heartbeat.

GaW8IPlWKDqIm1JMTSl3Zg.review_text: 5 stars for this place. Delicious food and $3 mimosas for brunch from 10-3pm on weekends. WORTH IT

GFsQZWu0s6e2d_rE2bABBw.review_text: Now  I am sure the brickhouse is an excellent restaurant and is delicious. This review is referring to my dinning experience only.    Ok so to start out, the restaurant was very accommodating, we did not wait too long before they had arranged some tables for us to sit at. The staff was pleasant and fairly on the ball with our mimosa and coffee orders. The atmosphere was cozier then I expected and they had a live person playing guitar in the background, so points for that.   I should mention that neither the coffee nor the mimosa were that good. The coffee was weak like an atrophied child and the mimosa was just a notch below "meh" quality. Actually, it was only $3 so I wont complain much.   On to the food. Here is where my dining experience takes a turn. I often battle between a few specific menu choices, and at the brickhouse was no different. The juevos rancheros and the Salmon Benedict were competing for my affection and as I had previously forgone salmon benedict at an earlier brunch I chose it here.  Oh how I regret that decision.  OK first off, I ordered the "salmon benny" with "House smoked (house caught) sock eye salmon." It was the novelty of this house caught smoked salmon that intrigued me. However, when my dish came, no smoked salmon! None at ALL! It was just cooked salmon! WTF! This infuriates me! Don't promise me smoked salmon (one of my favs) then deliver just cooked salmon ( not one of my favs). On top of this, it wasn't even really that good cooked salmon. Most of it just tasted like kinda fishy eggs. Admittedly, maybe I shouldn't order fish and eggs if I am not a huge fan of fishy tasting eggs, but that's not what I ordered! The best bites were the bits that were covered in the sauce so they have the dish some resemblance of a deeper flavor beyond unseasoned salmon and eggs. Usually, I prefer less sauce on my benedicts, but in this case, there need to be more. Overall, I was deeply unimpressed and deeply disappointed. Perhaps if I wasn't expecting smoked salmon then I would have been happier with my somewhat bland fishy eggs.  A quick note in the positive for the brickhouse. The girlfriend ordered the juevos rancheros, and was kind enough to let me try a bit. It tasted delicious and made me rue my choice of menu items even more. This is an important note because I am giving the brick house 2 stars because of the my eggy salmon debacle, even tho based on what everyone else ordered they probably deserved better. Actually, the more I think about it, if I am wanting to go back, then it deserves 3, since Id probably not go back to a 2 star place. So 3 stars for now, simply because of the potential I saw in the gfs food. was good too.

-b96Z_lO9BUmg9eggH_SHw.review_text: great menu -- veg/vegan friendly, and also lots of meat things too. laid back vibe, delicious food.

zORQY85qUfWiIEltLOxG1g.review_text: Longest wait in America.  Happy hour, forget it.  Lunch hour, forget it.  Each time I come here I would bitch and moan about the long wait and how it's always over-packed.  However, after taking a bite of my food, I would stop complaining and remember why I always return.  Oh yeah, I forgot to mention how amazing their tuna melts are and AMEN to their french fries with sauce.    Such a perfect lunch spot if you work close by.  Just try to come really early (11:15ish), before it gets too crowded.

fvtKAImpVmginXpilSeEow.review_text: I just loved the brunch here! We sat to the left of the front entrance and it was really nice because I felt like we were the only ones in the restaurant, even though there was a steady stream coming in and out. Anyway, we all had mimosas and coffee and the food was just amazing! I hope I get to stop by here someday to try their lunch as their garlic fries look spectacular.   If you're staying at a nearby hotel (like the Marriott Courtyard on 2nd St), this place is literally like 4 blocks from there and you can definitely just walk.

KUIv4oJcC2zKT1uiqURqHw.review_text: This place is definitely cute and has a very social and sophisticated edge to it.  It's located a few blocks away from the AT&T Ballpark.  I went here to try their Egg's Benedict.  I had hashbrowns on the side and fresh squeezed orange juice.  While I was waiting for my food, I received access to their WiFi so that I can work on my laptop.  The Egg's Benedict took about 15 minutes to arrive.  They forgot my orange juice until I reminded them about it.    The hashbrowns were pretty bland --they were actually just roasted potatoes. The Egg's Benedict did not impress me very much.  The eggs were not poached correctly and the inside of the egg was already 80% cooked.  The yolk is actually supposed to be runny once you pop it so that the yolk drippings can run through the English Muffin.  I was disappointed but it wasn't terrible.  The Hollandaise Sauce was fairly good but not too much on the creamy side.  The orange juice was really freshly squeezed and it was really refreshing.  If I return back here, I would not order the Egg's Benedict.  I'd probably get something else next time.

204pVFDT04PJyU8NgXhsQA.review_text: Top notch saloon food.  Good bang for the buck because of the hearty portions and staff is friendly and efficient.  I was most impressed with the atmosphere which was warm and inviting ("cozy: if you will)  ...  I'm a sucker for places like that.  The dipping sauces all could have used a little work The ranch dressing (onion rings), the au jus (cow tipper sandwich), and aioli that accompanied the jalapeno poppers  all seeming a bit thin and lacking flavor intensity but were by no means bad..  The have a very interesting and great happy hour deals..  Weekends too for pre/post Giants games.

DFENl5W4GgwGshWSgP3vbA.review_text: Went on a weekday for breakfast.  We arrived and the doors were open, and remained that way for most of breakfast.  Perhaps if it weren't in the 40's it would have been invigorating, but it was and I was freezing cold.  I had bacon and fruit salad.  They were fine.  My husband had poached eggs, potatoes and a biscuit.  Where do I start, the cold potatoes or the water logged eggs?  Let's do eggs, since they were the main part of the meal.  They were poached, but it seemed as if the kitchen was in dire need of a slotted spoon.  The eggs came in a small cup, which was filled 1/2 way up with water.  It was as if they just scooped the eggs out of the water, with that cup, and then put the cup on the plate.  My husband of course said nothing, and took a spoon and a napkin (this is not brain surgery folks) and drained them himself.  When he finally was set to eat his meal the potatoes were cold.  Could it be the cold air being ushered in through the wide open doors?  Me thinks it is a possibility.  Bottom line:  Burgers and fries, salads and sandwiches are the best items here.  The breakfast was mediocre, but have enjoyed their brunch.  I can't bring myself to lower the rating, but I can advise against the weekday breakfast.

vEu6rWir-VFssIiAjuKkVw.review_text: My fiancé and I stopped in for a bite to eat after we parked around the corner for a Giants game. I originally walked in because of the sign for a fish and chips sandwich and clam chowder. I'm a wee bit fond of clam chowder.   Anyway, I digress. I ended up having the Mexican burger, which is a jalapeño infused beef patty, pepper jack cheese, pico de gallo, and sour cream. I went sans sour cream, and used the chipotle aioli they have on hand. I must say, that was a pretty magical combination!  My fiancé had the Chicken Brie sandwich and absolutely loved it. She also commented that the garlic fries were better than at the ballpark. She also used the chipotle aioli and thought it was outstanding. She also had a glass of wine and we were both pleasantly surprised about the selection of wines they had.   We finished it off with a cookie dough milkshake that was out of this world. The only mark down on the whole experience was the fact that her fries were cold and my onion rings were just ok. Nevertheless, from now on, every time we come to a Giants game, we're going to stop and eat at the Brickhouse!

Valva2MGzBW8ux3641YINA.review_text: So I was waiting for some friends and decided to have a cocktail at the bar while waiting. The lady was very nice she got me the ginger Fizz minus the ginger and it was ok, still kinda pricey for Happy hour, $5. I decided to get a table before the place filled up, sat down, water was brought to the table, menus, they were ready for my group. I was waiting waiting, where is everyone?? I get a call we are here! I look around, um where? Maybe they are still walking. Then they call, where are you? I said sitting, where are you?...I was at the WRONG restaurant!!! OMG!!! I felt so dumb and felt so horrible they set up the table for me. I paid and ran out. The lady didn't give me a hard time, she was nice about it. Thanks for that! Oh and the food looked good, I think I will go back and actually eat next time.

-vRQ7m26rFlFbW7RpjRfLw.review_text: Just half a block from my place. Although there's nothing fancy about this place, but their sandwiches are really good. Try teriyaki marinated yellow tail tuna on focaccia or grilled chicken brie sandwich, you'll love it.   Oh, and the French fries are terrific--crisp and hot with perfectly soft interiors.  In a cold day, hot cider is a must!

H7I6AKkYu-1jemA5cEVu4w.review_text: Wagyu Beef:  All their burgers use 'wagyu'.  Menu explains that their 'wagyu' is Japanese brand of cattle raised in the U.S. and how you cannot rightfully label meat as 'Kobe Beef' unless cows are from a certain region in Japan.  With all this attention to the quality of meat, my hopes were up.   Burgers:  I really wanted to taste the burger, so I went for their basic 'Big Ass Burger' ($8.95).   Hmmmmmmmm.  Did using U.S. Wagyu make any difference?  Their burger just didn't leave any lasting impression.  I felt that the buns were too big.  I know it wasn't bad, but I've had better burgers in S.F.   Other notes:  I liked their casual and fun ambiance with high ceiling with wooden floors.  They have several nice booth tables.  Service was friendly.  $2 Blue Ribbon was their cheapest beer.  The French fries were the ordinary kind --- unexciting.  Go here with a Restaurant.com certificate or a coupon on the back of King Street Safeway receipt.

SFAeEA2hwfkMGTvqS87UYQ.review_text: The Brickhouse Cafe is a solid spot for a good, casual meal in SOMA. My friend and I walked in on a Tuesday night and were seated with no wait. He ordered the small ass burger, and I ordered the chicken brie sandwich. Both were good as was the service. The place feels cozy too on a cold night without a lot of pretense.

mkZDE0-VeiHakcofnG3HHg.review_text: I usually get my lunches at work catered but a few of my coworkers and I were not feeling our catered meal on that particular day and decided to venture out into SOMA for lunch. We were actually going to swing by Darwin's but of course, the line was insane and we decided to get searching. One of my coworkers suggested Brickhouse Cafe and the rest of us were indifferent about where to eat so the decision was made.  I got the Chicken Brie sandwich with the side salad of mixed greens. In hindsight, I should have done the upgrade to garlic fries or sweet potato fries instead of the salad because the fries actually smelled and looked very good. My sandwich came with sliced chicken breast, pesto mayo, brie, red onions, and apple on toasted foccocia bread. The filling of the sandwich was well-balanced and the flavors were great. The issue was the bread. It was a bit too toasted and my mouth got super scraped up. It was very uncomfortable :( This sandwich would have actually gotten 4 stars otherwise.

xVBq0d9jhedq1_8jVLDxXg.review_text: My favorite brunch place in SoMa. Awesome food at reasonable prices, and very rarely is there a wait for a table. Also, best breakfast sausages I've ever had.

cI5puqZckvEnpFGpwDOcKQ.review_text: Solid, consistent place for breakfast or lunch.  Have not had dinner here yet.  All the sandwiches are very tasty.  The Brickhouse melt is an automatic.  Salads are also good and serving sizes are fair.  They feature a "sandwich of the day" - and Friday is the "Fish and Chips" sandwich.  Hint: run, don't walk, to get this sandwich.  It is awesome!!

BCac3c30XVxN5yJyqGWv8Q.review_text: Terrible experiences at Brickhouse . . . staff unable to handle the guests they already had and continued seating new ones. It should be a good place to meet up for a cup of coffee, a drink or a quick bite before a ballgame and instead it's just frustrating.

sa7I1ZROWTfunqi4bLAUgw.review_text: Met a friend here to catch up on a Monday around 4:30.    I would describe the inside style as eclectic western.  I ordered an irish coffee to start out with - it was really good!    Wait staff was friendly, served us right away and let us know that the menu switched at 5pm.    all of us decided to order off the happy hour menu.   I ordered the cornmeal jalapeno calamari, my boyfriend got the garlic fries and my friend ordered that talapia fish tacos.    All these items were $6 during happy hour which runs from 4:30-6:30.  The garlic fries were superb and my friend enjoyed her tacos.  Unfortunately the calamari was a dud!  There were pieces I couldn't chew threw and no hint of a taste of the jalapenos.   Most of the experience was good so I'd give the Brick House Cafe another go if I find myself back in SF.

GmKbX2fbZuclKsk-9lEvaw.review_text: Maybe it's my fault for ordering a salad at this type of place, but then going here wasn't my choice and I do love salads.  Got the spring kale salad with chicken.  $10 for the salad plus $4 for the chicken.  Tasty?  Yes.  And the dressing was very good, as the woman at the registered had informed me.  But with less than 2 oz of chopped up chicken on the salad, lousy value.  I paid an extra $4 for a sprinkling of chicken???  And yet their burgers (~$11-12) are HUGE.  WTF?  Still hungry when I walked out.

-OODneV01sxed0jBUv8XVg.review_text: I am a big fan of Brickhouse.  I always tend to forget they are open on weekends, but on Sunday...I was craving for their Brickhouse Melt.  I got ready and walked over to get my food to go.  There is a huge selection for burgers...so if you like your burgers with different options...this is the place to go.

bk3LC4qjyk3VEVtpP4P68w.review_text: I can't remember if I have reviewed them before.  Its a decent burger joint convienent for after work drinks...But their vegetarian chilli is outstanding.  It is a thick stew, not too spicy and full of veggie goodness that I think I got my entire veggie serving for the day at lunch....which is more than I can say for their apple cider, which I believe to be just heated apple juice...

_Ai8Q8__Wk0lF367Pw0Ljg.review_text: Really. comfortable atmosphere and attentive, understated service.  The vegan burger with a hot ginger toddy was great!  Everyone here seems to enjoy themselves and shares that.  A lot of creative drink options and much more than bar food.  Worth a stop.

cmAHVj0b5Wz5Tun6Op0ksw.review_text: For some reason I pictured the brick house to be like thristy bear. Boy was I wrong.  Small and homey.  Came here last night for some beers after the Phillies vs. Giants game.  A friend of a friend of a friend is friend's with the owner.  It was a Monday night and it was slow.  Mostly old men. Blah. Interested in trying the food here, although there are many poor reviews.

Y3ghf_C-b-VJeFl-hcXwEQ.review_text: Weekend brunch in SoMA becomes a no-brainer at the Brickhouse Cafe--which works out for me, because I've usually said adios to too many brain cells come Sunday morning.    With a decor that can best be described as John Wayne's hipster version of a Cracker Barrel, Brickhouse serves up a great mix of breakfast (try the vanilla bean french toast) and lunch fare (French dip with au jus) options.  Sit back on the cushioned wingback chairs by the front windows and take in the mellow elevator tunes of their weekend guitarist (who grinds out easy listening acoustic hits of the 90s, like "More Than Words"); you'll find this is the perfect place to detox from last night's drunkeness and debauchery.    Or, if you'd like to keep the party going, they've got $3 mimosas and $5 Bloody Marys.  You heard it here first-- Day Drinking is back en vougue, and if you're not in the mood for detox, Brickhouse Cafe is more than willing to induldge you.

ICwMfseYkrB0ZEK8tDUOHw.review_text: Brunch here was---dare I say it---eggcellent. Sorry, I dared.  Huevos rancheros and a Bloody Mary started my Sunday off exactly right. That, and the great company of a few fellow Yelp CMs.  Brickhouse is a comfy, cozy spot, with lots of indoor greenery and distressed wood. The atmosphere and the jovial staff make you feel at home right away. Or like going over to your friend's house for brunch.   The huevos rancheros were nicely done, as were the creamy grits that came as a side order to my friend's meal. I usually don't care for grits and know positively nothing about what authentic grits are supposed to taste like, so take that as you will.   I'll definitely make it a point to head back here next time I'm in SF.

pq_LC58aF1_5grJqclWn9Q.review_text: My co-worker took me here....Cool swanky place with character! The both times I came here I felt like a burger.  -I ordered the Calfornian twice....first time I got a turkey substitute..will cost you $1 extra....wow first time I've had to pay extra $ for a ground turkey substiute. The second time they accidentally gave me a chicken fillet. -+$1 to add bacon -I like that you can get a side salad instead of fries. -They have yummy bags of homemade chips...so yummy, but greasy... felt too guilty to purchase -They have fresh squeezed lemonade for $3 -Order at counter, drinks are handled seperately at the bar, Sit down, staff brings you your food or calls out your # if you order to go. -Easy...pesasy -Lunch (sandwich/burge with fries or salad & drink) will run you about $10-$15  3.5 stars.....Pretty cool lunch spot if you work in the area!!!

oDa9wgyowQiKkgTG9cPNJw.review_text: Cool barn-like space full of shabby chic furniture. There's no table service, so you wait on line to order, pay and then scout out a seat. The food is casual American (sandwiches, soups and salads) with tempting combinations like chicken, brie, and apple on focaccia bread. I really liked the sandwich, but the tomato soup was too sweet and tasted like it could have come out of a can.

mwS4irtU87ffD5klPL8JGQ.review_text: Used a coupon from bloomspot for 36.00 and used  28.00 and got charged 18% plus tax making it more expensive than not buying the coupon.  Such a charming place.  4 for the food, 2 for the service.  I was in here for brunch on the weekend, and it wasn't that crowded so the ewaiter came by 3 times and we felt we were not ordering fast enough, .however, you would think the waiter was working on 15 other tables after that (he wasn't, and there was other staff).

N-CtWs8EUn0Oq1Rqm49Wkg.review_text: I love this place. Truly a hidden gem.

YFNAYiWUDuNqv57VS5tXPg.review_text: This is one of two go to spots for weekend breakfast. They have a great Vanilla Bean french toast I love! They also have fresh OJ, and delicious bacon. Not the cheapest place, but good food.

VK-ds3dGSSBoavkFde3e2Q.review_text: Small 2 story restaurant that is warm and inviting, yet in an industrial way. (It is in the SOMA / Ballpark area after all) But if you live in the area, it's conveniently located on Brannan, it's usually sunny, and it's casual with your standard American faire, including burgers, beer, and a brunch menu. It's close the ballpark, so if you want to spend the day in the area or get together before a game, this is an option.   I'm not wowed particularly by the food, it was good but nothing stands out of the ordinary to me in memory. But what does stand out for me, is that for a group of 9 girls, we were treated with horrible service. They mixed up our group and separated us when seating us, the waitress was slow in bringing out drinks whenever we were out, and she NO patience in taking our orders, she was actually snappy to us.   Really? 9 nice girls that are just there to catch up, munch on some food and have a good time. Also these 9 girls are more than generous tippers.   But oh no she was rude. And when we mentioned it to her colleague, another waiter he got on the defense right away. (As he should defend a coworker.......) But we weren't mean, why so sensitive?

tFId1_3TcZLzp4lhrjYLWg.review_text: Wanting to avoid the hour-long waits at every brunch place across the city and being armed with vehicles for once, we decided to drive to SOMA to check out Brickhouse. I wasn't disappointed. This cafe has an awesome country western theme, complete with live music at 11 AM! There was a guitarist playing John Denver, and he fit in perfectly with the decor.  Our food was simple, delicious, and filling, and the wait was short. That's a Sunday morning win for me.

VWdnGFOkKZT87jUm5s9ArA.review_text: Not Impressed...   My husband and I decided to go out for a nice dinner when I was super pregnant so we were walking along and decided to stop into Brickhouse Cafe. It was expensive for pretty crappy food. The only thing that was worth mentioning was their homemade ginger ale. It was spicy and delicious! Not like any other ginger ale I have ever had.  Now, the real reason why this place gets so little stars is because it was a hot night for San Francisco and I had a bottle of ketchup explode on my huge, pregnant belly while wearing a white shirt. The server was hardly unapologetic and blamed the incident. I mean, I know it wasn't her fault but you should apologize and at least offer to comp a few dollars off our bill for dry cleaning but not even an offer.  I will not be visiting this place again

WIo1EGGa9ZSPjgwUM2Mz7g.review_text: Overall a solid brunch spot in SOMA (and surprisingly, there are not as many brunch spots as I would have thought within walking distance from our area in SOMA).  I got the short-stack pancakes, which were pretty much as expected (and a little pricey at $5.50 for two pancakes).  Also, had a banana shake, and the shake I would say is the best item at the place (they have a different shake of the day that rotates, at least on weekends).  Waitstaff friendly, but again, nothing that stood out either.

AxJNQAe5DVEIcSdOSOo3Yg.review_text: Stopped in here again for another shot with the burger for lunch yesterday at the manager's invitation, and LOVED it.  Ethan took great care of me and when I got my burger it was a lovely and juicy medium rare with grill marks and A1 on the table.  Yum!  The onion rings did not disappoint again, either.  Can't wait to go back--might have to make this a renewed tradition.  :)

V8f5ZvaS7-vNdfF316IBFQ.review_text: Calamari was great. little on the garlicy side but I liked it. This place offers you a different experience of your everyday restaurant, it has "character"

h84yrjuSurX1kSJ4thAfQA.review_text: I have eaten here twice in a row this week. I plan on going again tomorrow. 3rd time's a charm, right?   Best Veggie Chili around and the Yellow Tail sandwich (plus fries!) is delish. The lunch line is short just before noon and picks up at noon on the dot. The line moves fast so don't hesitate if there's a long one when you get there. The tables turnover fast too!   Can't wait to try the Carmel Cider tomorrow!

mABRVuOSz8MEpe4VMHk0kw.review_text: Location: A+ (close to the abode)  Service: A -- super nice, chill waitress. the guy who poured our water has a sense of humor hiding in there. check him out.  Atmosphere: B+    it's a little dark inside -- but a cozy kind of dark. it's very chill. one guy was in a suit. another in a pair of shorts. no stuff shirts here.  Parking: Ungraded. My husband seems to attract parking tickets (4 in one month -- GROAN.  me thinks it could be the husband -- and not the fact that parking is an issue (it's not).  Husband: F  Food: C-   BUT WAIT. i can see that some folks would really like their food. its more of a "down home cooking with some style' (think beef stroganoff with interesting things in it). back to hubby again. he taught me about food quality. PRE-HUBBY: i would snarf on whatever -- claiming it all to be exquisite (direct correlation between happy exclamations and not cooking). he's a foodie ((he's chinese, what can i say? hands down, they are the BEST FOOD EXPERTS. no food channel for me. i just float my food questions to the pillow next to mine).   based on this sophisticate palate training, their food isn't on par with other $$ restaurants i've eaten at in SOMA - or in the Bay Area overall. i thought it was a little too salty (crab dip app). the salad dressings were dull (had the Pear and Iceberg salads). the rosemary chicken was very good (potatoes and bok choy cooked perfectly). the butter/dip/something for the sourdough was flavorless. the water was really watery.  I do hear that they have a "fun bar." we didn't check it out.

pS4UhhwhSGQEnrC20FMe8Q.review_text: Last week I stumbled into Brickhouse planning to hunker down with my laptop and a coffee for a few hours in the afternoon. When I got to the counter I noticed a sign that said "Free Wi-Fi. Please only make use of this after 2 pm." (Something very close to those words exactly). So I thought, great its just after two, no problem.   I ordered my drink, sat down and found that I couldn't connect to the internet. I went to the counter and asked the woman, "Do I need a certain password or something that I'm missing for the wireless?" She handed me a card with the wireless name and password. I sit down again, type it in and it still won't connect. A different worker passes by my table and I ask her if there's something wrong with the wireless to which she replies: "Yeah, the wireless doesn't really work, it never has. I think I've gotten it to work twice ever maybe. I don't know why we even advertise for it. I don't really think there's anything else in this neighbord except for Starbucks, and that's (tilt of the head) Starbucks"  First of all, I too would REALLY like to know as well, why you advertise for free wireless if it plainly and simply doesn't work. I'd like to know why the first employee I asked about it didn't happen to mention a thing, and I'd like to know how many customers have been driven away in the past because of this false advertising. I find it especially ironic that there's a sign next to the register advertising their new ten dollar minimum on credit cards because "this recession is killing us!!!" Maybe you all should step up your game, get your wireless fixed once and you could be opening your doors to a whole host of missing customers in those lonely late afternoon hours.   I'm sure as a business owner, the image of hoardes of laptop bearing, two dollar coffee sipping people infesting your place all afternoon is far from your favorite. But keep in mind people who work also eat sometimes too. I'm sure you could take a nod from some of your more successful competitors and figure out how they manage to maintain a consistent lunch, laptop and happy hour crowd, and are, surviving the recession.  I'm mad on principal, I feel like you tried to fool me Brickhouse. Just take your sign down at least!

RhOMDvLhQG62l6hhcgtiPg.review_text: PLEASE help me understand why no one has mentioned the Tequila Peach Pork Chop.  I have eaten this same dish the two times I've been to Brickhouse, and am proud to say it is now on my list of my favorite dishes in SF. (p.s. there are only 3 dishes on the list so far, it's that good.)  Start with a pork chop bigger than your face, surround it with their super-creamy golden polenta grits and a maple-y sauce, then add fresh, grilled peaches and fried plantains on the side!  Comfort food at its finest...this and a Little Star Pizza would be my last meal before the gas chamber, hands down.

DCEy-NYoOKf-QZoo0oGIjw.review_text: This place is ok. A dad and his kid swooped the table we wanted right before us (a party of 4) and then the hostess tried to seat us at the bar. We waited for a tall table in the bar area instead so we could talk...the server was super slow to greet us. But I got really excited about the $3 mimosas! I had 2, yum! Brunch was pretty good but nothing special. May come back for brunch before a giants game or something.

gZmEZvZwLJH7JiQfIdbkRQ.review_text: This is my second time here and I'm thinkin the food just gets better and better! I tried their 8 oz wagyu kobe burger, cooked medium, and added avocado and an egg. The burger was cooked perfectly and was juicy all the way to the last bite!   I almost ordered the 11 oz "big ass burger" but this burger was plenty to top me off along with the side of fries and pesto basil aioli! Very attentive and friendly staff. This is a great place to pregame and grab some drinks and eats before the Giants game. Try a burger any burger!

hap3kh1KBtruI7Fh8IS14g.review_text: Their french dip sandwich is so good! also the atmosphere is really nice. Very hole in the wall vibe.  The only downside was the orders were messed up (drinks and entrees switched) and there was only one waitress while I was there for dinner. I also had to ask to get my water refilled. Seemed understaffed.  Nonetheless I would go there again :)

YbZg36FoMgkKcTEPae5siA.review_text: Brunch is one of those meals where you can eat enough to tide you over til dinner if it's done right. The extensive menu and tasty breakfast choices were quite alluring when I stopped in with a friend on a Sunday afternoon. SoMA is dead on Sundays at least before noon. My friend got a caramel flavored coffee, we split onion rings and then I got a scramble and she got the fritatta. There was a lot of food to be eaten. They also have $3 mimosas.   Live violin was playing in the background but the sound wasn't terribly overwhelming. The staff were good. Overall, this is a decent place to eat. I would definitely come back to try lunch here.

E7vYv80945tWZe0Qiswyjg.review_text: Gotta say, food was good, but service left a lot to  be desired. ::EDIT:: Follow-up from management over poor service is a great thing.  My compliments to Kim.  I have to say this again, though: great food.  I'll be coming back later =D

IkFjRnnI5trMcwHHl_1Vrg.review_text: I've lived down the street for years and had never actually been here for dinner--- and I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.  Had a cozy dinner here on a rainy Friday night, and it was just what I needed.  The band was playing music in the front area and there was a comfortable and busy vibe to the place: not too crowded, but certainly not empty.  We had a booth for the 4 of us and were served our food nice and quickly:  Buffalo burger, polenta fries, HUGE spinach salad (which was really really good) and some beers.    All in all, it was exactly what I wanted.  I found the food to be fresh, filling and good.  A cozier and less-expensive dinner alternative to my other casual go-to spot in the hood- 21st Amendment.  I think I'm switching over to Brick House.

Hxp9KgF2TPOln6bSAf2aBA.review_text: I've been here for lunch and dinner and must say, if it's right before a giants game, it's gonna be loud -so just be warned. The first time around I had a burger since that is what they seem to be all about when you look at their menu. It's wasn't the most amazing burger I've ever had but I liked all of the options they had; including turkey burgers for those looking for a slightly healthier option. More recently, I went in for lunch and had the roast beef sandwich that had melted white cheddar, caramelized onions, arugula and an awesome horseradish spread on it. It was AMAZING! The horseradish had just enough kick to it. I also substituted in some sweet potato fries for $2 more but you can also sub in garlic friends or beer battered onion rings.

wb2I6PxYjRStE7OGLL4S7A.review_text: Other than their extremely slow service and messing up the order half the time their food is pretty good.  I've been coming here for over 4 years and my favorite go-to lunch options are:   Chicken Brie Sandwich Veggie Melt & Tomato Basil Bisque  Brickhouse Salad  The prices aren't the best in the area but the food is decent and consistent. They have an upstairs seating area in addition to their tables downstairs and is good for groups up to 10 or less.  They have a decent happy hour as well:  HAPPY HOUR: (Monday through Saturday 4:30pm -- 6:30pm) $3 Draft Micro Brews $1 off Well and Call Liquors $2 Pabst... always $2 off Bar Food Menu

ZKlOnMidHbjqmCaeb5utyw.review_text: After wandering aimlessly around SOMA in search of a new place to eat lunch (I work right next to AT&T Park), we settled on Brickhouse.  Quite the letdown.  Firstly, if a salad is going to have your restaurants name in the title, it better be good.  Like real good.  LIke when I'm chatting with friends and they mention Brickhouse I can go, "you know---their Brickhouse Salad is just to die for".  Secondly, don't give me a mixed green salad full of frisee.  It's unpalatable and quite frankly unacceptable.  Also, if you're going to say your putting candied nuts, pear, and tomato in a salad....um, make sure they're in there.  It was like a bad scavenger hunt.

s4TB2oNJKW1zRFSbBUC-hw.review_text: I'm completely done with Brickhouse.  And I have given this place PLENTY of chances.  The waitstaff is alternately spacey, rude or they think that they are just so 'terminally hip' that they can get away with really bad service. The food's not good enough to suffer through 'attitude'.   The burgers are just OK, and never, ever order the corned beef hash. It tasted like the meat had died and rotted way before they boiled it into oblivion and slapped it on a plate. And the poached eggs were hard boiled. Even tabasco could not salvage that awful mess.    There's a reason why this place has the nickname of "The Poophouse Cafe".

SmtosmsnuxNnIMahlMD6Rw.review_text: The burgers here are amazing. Will be coming back.

kuneGV2rgWY6gLYwncZuaQ.review_text: Ian at the counter told me the bluesy bacon would be magical. He wasn't exaggerating! Always love the burgers and the ambiance here. Super friendly staff, and really good music as well.

09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w.review_text: I noticed only one TV here, but they had Manchester United vs. Blackburn Rovers on (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…) ... so, a big plus right there! Four stars for lunch. Three stars for Happy Hour. Either way, I would go back since the location is basically SOMA. If coming from FiDi and elsewhere, then it's too out of the way. Due to its many windows, the place is bright (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…). Another plus is it is not crowded like the other bars and HH places closer to downtown. At lunch, I tried the mushroom burger and it was huge (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…). It was really good and did not get soggy quickly. The fries that came with it were on the salty side compared to other places, but that's how I like them. However, that seemed to be the theme for Happy Hour bar foods. Everything I tried was salty; garlic fries, fried calamari, meatballs (which is really good and recommended by the way). Still, the Happy Hour prices are not bad: Happy Hour menu (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…). Bar food menu (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…). Drinks list specials (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…). Beers list (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…). Bonus review: The Anderson Valley Oatmeal Stout is really good. Since I like Guinness, this was similar and like drinking a cold cocoa (yelp.com/biz_photos/HCTO…).

fES_Ws1CDBUw7vcTJzr8CA.review_text: Brickhouse is rapidly becoming a Giants pre-game spot for me (as I tend to park nearby).  I have yet to delve deeply into the food menu, but in addition to numerous enticing draft beers, this place has great milkshakes, root beer floats, and even a Guinness Float!  The menu looks tempting but for one reason or another, the only item I have had was an enjoyable french onion soup.  Prices are reasonable and I will return soon, and look forward to reporting on a meal.

-9Hs_TQy20gudebsCJHUnA.review_text: This is another neighborhood spot for us. The food is good, especially the burgers and eggs. Last time I went, I had a turkey burger patty with the hangover toppings (fried egg and gravy), and it was very tasty.   The only real problem with the place is that I am not sure what exactly it is supposed to be. It has a nice small bar, and lots of tables, so seating has never been a problem. They have a lot of pride in their food, but non of it is really top notch or gourmet, just very good. And they only have one tv which is often blocked by a post, depending on where you sit.

REGjppkq2IkDLRQVmRj_Bg.review_text: Brickhouse Cafe is a diamond in the rough.  The place has a lot of potential and lives up to the quality of service you'd expect from a San Francisco eatery.  I've only been during lunch but the live music sounds awfully enticing on a nighttime adventure.    The food was great.  I ordered a sandwich that met every expectation put forth.  The "cafe" also serves coffee and tasty treats throughout the day.  Make sure to check this place out to get your own feedback but Brickhouse shouldn't disappoint.

0D9mzs20FoLfDRFTYO9qVQ.review_text: I'm glad my sister was late this morning...    A definite local spot, and the biscuits and gravy over eggs were fabulous.  HIt the spot for brunch with me!  Looking forward to hanging there more often.    I also noticed a happy hour theme everyday.  I'm sure it's worth checking out as well.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: So here's a bit of a shocker. I'm giving Brickhouse five stars for my two recent dining experiences there. Why did you slap your forehead? Yes, five stars because it's mighty might just lettin' it all hang out. And she's the one, the only one who's built like an am-a-ka-zawn.... what did Lionel Richie just say? Anyway, I had originally written off Brickhouse as a ballpark hangout for people who wear those orange styrofoam fingers while eating drippy chicken wings and downing some brewskis. But I guess I was mistaken. Dinner is the option to take.   Jamie W. and I came here last week with zero expectations. We were going to grab a bite at 21st Amendment, but as usual, it was packed. Ozone was blaring Eurotrash dance music through their patio speakers. Alas, when we sat down and saw the menu, it really just looked like your standard brewpub selections - burgers, ribs, fish n' chips - nothing that sounded wow. As we do at Perry's, we shared an $8 Wedge Salad, which was frankly much better than the one at Perry's (see photo). I think the key differences were the size and quality of the pancetta and the addition of crispy leeks and cucumber chunks that made it fuller in flavor.   Jamie ordered the $14 Stick-to-Your-Ribs Baby Back Ribs, which was a hefty slab of fork-tender pork over fries (see photo). Timing is everything as he just ordered almost the same thing at the Tee Off Bar in the Outer Richmond. There the overly sweet sauce completely overpowered the ribs that had been in the smoker a little too long. At Brickhouse, the sauce was more mild and modest in portion, and the rib meat was moist. Mine was a true unexpected winner, the $18 Brandy Apple Pork Chop, which was honestly one of the best prepared pork chops I've had at a restaurant (see photo). Seasoned nicely outside and moist inside. The grilled apple slices on top, usually a death knell for such an all-American dish, were just the right consistency and sweetness to offset the savory.   It came with grilled asparagus and golden polenta grits, which were a tasty, chunky alternative to the more predictable mashed potatoes. So the question became... was this just a fluke? I held back on a review until our second visit last night. This time, the place was packed. There was live music from a sadly ignored jazz duo performing buttery smooth standards. Lots of young T-shirted guys, colleagues obviously, have congregated for after-work eats. We managed to score a corner table with a view of the duo.   We decided to share the $12 Organic Beet and Arugula Salad, which you should be forewarned is a massive pile of green (see photo). Delicious with a monstrous grilled portobello mushroom sliced on one side and big wedges of red beets on the other. Smaller beet cubes, goat cheese and toasted walnuts finished the dish. This time, Jamie tried the $14 Anchor Steam Beer-Battered Fish n' Chips, two large, tasty and lightly crisped filets over fries with a remoulade dipping sauce (see photo).   Mine was even more back-to-basics, the $16 Rosemary Roasted Half Chicken with Mashed Potatoes and Asparagus (see photo). Sounds like a Marie Callendar frozen dinner, doesn't it? It's all in the execution - moist inside and with a nice savory sauce. There is nothing revolutionary about the food. It's simply and honestly satisfying food, especially after a taxing day at the office. The eclectic Victorian vibe is comforting with the waitresses on both occasions really attentive no matter how many diners there were. It's a cozy neighborhood place that probably doesn't need much crosstown traffic to survive. That just means more pork chops for me.   FOOD - 5 stars...yes, can you believe it?... excellent traditional brewpub fare really well executed  AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...warm vibe makes you want to hang out on a weeknight to avoid the cold world outside  SERVICE - 5 stars...really attentive with no fuss or pretension  TOTAL - 5 stars...it's mighty might just lettin' it all hang out!

99cFO-gTl6JOOR_FxFjKQA.review_text: i like this place and do come here at lease twice a week.. but lately i'm quite disappointed with their services ( for just one particular staff i guess! everyone else was very friendly ) i called in advance for pick up and double checked with the person on the phone of my orders, later, i came in, waited in line to pay and found out they didn't even get my order... the guy i order food with he didn't even apologize. or seem to care. i didn't have another 15 - 20 mins to wait around so i left n i went to work hungry and upset..!

G0jy3hldFyLBbxtMoF4PkA.review_text: I finally got to come here for dinner and had some very delicious fish and chip!. Nice and fresh with not too much batter. The garlic fries were decent, but nothing to write home about.  It was a shame that most of the time I was there, the live band was on break. But what a wonderful atmosphere they create in conjunction with the delicate, yet sort of rustic mood the restaurant sets with its decor.

pJQNx6BsCyYGNNYlFdnfAQ.review_text: Love this place no matter what time of the day.  Drinks are great!  Food is wonderful!  Love that the health rating is 100!  Very friendly staff & great food is what you'll get here.

DQTaK-tXD5FGxQemEUCSvg.review_text: I have really mixed feeling reading this place. I think most of the staff and the owners and friendly and happy and want to do good. But they are the slowest when it comes to making food. I' m not talking about during the busy lunch hour, that I understand with a ton of people all at once. The mornings when there is one or two customers it usually takes 10-15 minutes to just get a bagel with cream cheese. I guess the cooks are prepping for the day. No sense or urgency at all. I stopped going there after more than once having to ask the counter person if my bagel was ready yet. It's close to my office, they use good ingredients, but they only seem to care about prepping for the lunch people. It's too bad. Stopped going there, doubt I would give them ano0ther chance after so many failures.

wv9TJQOarafDdfSgb0ogrA.review_text: Love this place! Moved to the area and have already been 3 times. Their brunch menu is amazing. Quite heavy and rich but delicious. Also a huge fan of the pesto mashed potatoes. Everything is very fresh here and you can tell with every bite. The bartender, Stefan, was crazy nice and very helpful when we couldn't decide what to order. Highly recommend the pulled pork bennie and the French toast. Wait staff is very friendly and attentive to needs. Also very knowledgable of their menu and the origins of ingredients. Will be coming back.

aIFbo8WaP6SCuOFnj_v9kA.review_text: This place has potential in terms of atmosphere and general ambiance.  The food is just ok. Sounds better than it is.  Our table had a "big ass" burger, a shredded bbq salmon sandwich, beet salad with chicken and apple crisp.  The salmon was a strange concept and overly sweet. The beets were obviously from a tin, the chicken on my salad was pounded as thin as veal and overly dry, the burger was dry as well as the apple crisp - which was more like dehydrated apple slices in a ramekin with some crumbled graham crackers on top.....not worth the price of a dessert at all.  Service was spotty.  I had a great groupon for this place; so, we went, but we won't return.

kfOmFjP_h9Sdnh29UkPLRA.review_text: I usually love the Brickhouse but this last visit left a sour taste in my mouth. The waitress was clueless and my cocktail had fruit flies in it. Generally, the staff was far more interested in the Giants game than their customers. Total strike out.

0wh7vg1Z_ekHyr6DbBjHRQ.review_text: I've been to this restaurant several times, and I really wanted to make it work. It's very close to my bf's apartment, and the food is pretty decent. HOWEVER, the service is horrendous. The first time we went here, the food took at least 45 minutes to arrive, and we were only ordering breakfast. We also waited a long time just to have someone take our order.  The last time I was here, we waited for a good 5 minutes to be seated. We ended up leaving because I was starving, and nobody even acknowledged our existence.  I think they genuinely just don't care at this place. I've grown too old to tolerate such poor customer service.

cZTwv-ipWAPqQeKVeRex7g.review_text: For the approximate 5 years I've been working in this area, I've been to Brickhouse maybe 5 or so times.  I dunno, I was just never really impressed with the burgers (which is what I always get here).  But not being able to come up with a fresh option on an already sleepy Monday, I found myself back here once again.  This time, though, I didn't even look at the burger section of the menu.  Feeling like I should be somewhat healthy today, I went with the "Full On Turkey."  I gotta say, it wasn't bad.  It comes with tomato, sprouts, cucumbers (which I really enjoyed), avocado, provolone, mayo, and dijon.  The dijon was a bit strong, but the "Butt Load Fries" counteracted that taste nicely.  (The fries, by the way, are pretty damn good.)  Like everyone else mentioned, the line is long so plan accordingly.  I'd say try and come before the noon rush for sure.  They have seating upstairs as well.  The few other times I've been here, I remember saying to myself I wouldn't be back for a while.  But I didn't say that this time and I really want to try the Chicken Brie sammich everyone is talking about.  Til next time...

LoRQeclsYws6ysbjHG4bUw.review_text: WHOA.  The level of confusion and bewilderment at this establishment was almost unfathomable.  I had to give the place 3 stars for the food, ambiance and good intentions of the waiter.  Let me walk through the sequence of events. 1. 6/22: Call to make a reservation for 6 people at 10:30 on Saturday, 6/25.  It took approximately 4 and 1/2  minutes for the person to locate the reservation book (if one exists ... is that what she was doing?), but she confirmed the res. 2. 6/24: Call to change the res to 10 people, still at 10:30.  The host says to me, "What's your name?  I don't see that we have you down, but ok.  We don't normally take reservations before Game Day...especially a Bobblehad Game Day."  WHAT?  No one told me this before.  I am realizing hope will be my next strategy. 3.6/25, 10:40 Arrive with 8 people (2 bailed, booooooo) and we're seated promptly, HOPE WORKED! 4. 11:20ish: Not.So.Fast.  Hope is not working.  We are trying to order drinks whenever we see anyone because our waiter (super nice, but way overwhelmed and may be only 1 of 2 waiters on a Bobblehad Game Day) is definitely not asking us if we "need" anything anymore.  He eventually comes by and takes our food order 5. 11:50ish...first round of food comes.  I got my plate, score!  3 of my friends, however, did not. 6. 12:00: Still no food for 2 of my friends (losing patience and understanding). 7. 12:15:  Last 2 plates come and those of us who waited (sorry, not me) are eating ice cold fries and onion rings. 8. 12:30 Finishing up and auto tip is already on the check because we were a large party.   I in no way fault the waiters, but seriously, management needs to handle the Big Game Days in a more organized and prepared way.  This place is one of only a handful of brunch spots near the ball park.  I will be back, just not anywhere close to first pitch.

rCLaP1XwqaECVT4pa8GOUw.review_text: Brickhouse was my favorite lunch spot for years (been coming here since 2005). The Brickhouse melt was THE best sandwich in SoMA. Sadly, it has been purged with the new menu. Tried the Wagyu burger today, with sweet potato fries. Several problems with the lunch; the lettuce was limp/wilting, and onions soggy/limp. The buns were burnt. the burger wasn't anything special. It was juicy, I'll give them that, but there wasn't much flavor for the ensemble as a whole. (served dry w/no sauce) The fries were overcooked, dry and on the edge of burnt. All said, for 20+ bucks (I had cheese for an extra buck, with tip $25 total), I'd rather eat an Umami. New menu + higher prices + poorer quality = Brickhouse has jumped the shark :(

N5z08ILUOTAizKIdEOsPbw.review_text: I had a great lunch here today and will definitely go back. I went after the lunch rush at about 2pm. Great fish sandwhich on fluffy foccacia. Fast service and good malt vinegar for fries. Solid lunch spot in SOMA

1Qy1KOOia9W9_8oQI83glQ.review_text: I love this place.  Friendly staff.  Has Wifi.  Pretty decent food.  Centrally located.

GmqtrGT0VJV6vdicmy-qdA.review_text: Marginal food, marginal service, and orange juice from concentrate.

V4unpKMFq8kSHDMw2UW9rQ.review_text: The Food - My Honey Chipotle Pulled Pork was pretty awesome. The artisanal bread was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. There was a good amount of pulled pork inside. The pork had a pleasant spicy kick to it that was offset by coleslaw. That said, I was expecting my $10 to go a little farther than a modestly-sized sandwich and a small salad of mixed greens.   The Wait - A bunch of coworkers and I ordered to-go. Now I don't mind waiting for food to be prepared, but when 6 out of 7 orders come out and we sit there waiting 10 minutes for the last to come out, it's kind of annoying. Especially when I'm hungry and need to sit there ogling that temptress of a sandwich.

zohCjiRdolmMAmrNflNC8g.review_text: Sooo... I've been a fan of the Brick House Cafe, and the Brickhouse Melt sandwich for years.  I went for lunch today and had this exchange at the counter:  Me:  I'd like the Brickhouse Melt please  Manager:  Sorry, it's not on the menu anymore.  We are redoing the menu.  Me:  Uhhh.... really.  Gee, it's like a signature item for this place.  Named after the establishment.  Manager:  Yeah, it's been on the menu for nearly 20 years, but we wanted to make a change.  Me:  I see... so I guess it just wasn't selling very well ?  Manager:  Oh no, it sold really well, but we thought we'd like to make a change and take if off the menu.  Me:  Uhhh... OK... but that really doesn't make sense.  I could see if you weren't selling them, or if people didn't like them.    Thinking to myself now:  Do you understand the concept of repeat business and signature items ?  I also looked up reviews of the Brickhouse Melt sandwich on Yelp - people LOVED IT, and wrote about it often.  Back to the Manager, who said:  No, they were selling.  We just wanted to make some changes.  Do you want to try the Turkey Club instead?    Me:  Yeah, sure.    So I tried the Turkey Club. It's OK, but NOT a club sandwich at all.  Accordingly to Wikipedia (i.e. source for ALL KNOWLEDGE, ha ha) a "Club Sandwich" is a multi-layered construct made with toasted (flat) bread- usually 3 layers in my experience, and (because of it's nice height) held together with toothpicks.    This Turkey "Club" was on a hoagie-style roll of french bread.  Not bad, but not a "Club".    Yeah, sure, so you might say that not all "club" sandwiches are multi-layered, but MOST are.  So when you name an item a "club sandwich" the majority-vote expectation of the person ordering it is that it will be like other "club" sandwiches.  This one was not.  And it was not nearly as good as the now defunct "Brickhouse Melt".  Damn that was one great sandwich.  I shudder to think of all the other great items that may have been deleted from the menu under the ridiculous logic being adhered to by the person that decided to "redo" the new Brick House Cafe menu.  Not sure if I'll find out.  Not sure if I'm going back.  There is never-ending silliness and entertainment in this world... if you just pay attention.

6-AA014-IT2FJjcEqJBZYg.review_text: I am upset with my culpably unsatisfied order.. A Chicken Caesar Cold Sandwich with a side of fries today for lunch.  I had it to-go because I wanted to avoid the lunch crowd here during the hour that I was here.  Sadly, when the time came for me to get my big-girl hands in there, especially considering that at this point my appetite was beyond whet. They gave me a side-salad by mistake, instead of my much desired fries.  My mouth was practically watering.    Seriously? A Chicken Caesar Sandwich; which.. is practically a Caesar Salad between two slabs of focaccia, plus more salad?  Might as well have included a small diet-coke in the order...  Brickhouse Cafe, what are you suggesting here..?   I don't know you well enough for you to be implying such inconsiderate things.   I am insulted, and the sandwich wasn't even that good.

CpYy-uIO7V5TY30DnkoeOw.review_text: For some reason, perhaps the feeling that there's something more interesting to be doing than driving around on fossil fuel, I'm always noticing the scenery when ghost riding my whip around town.  Last thursday, Brickhouse Cafe, with lights all aglow and wafting sweet holiday aromas, became the beneficiary of this ADD tendency, as I stocked away a mental note to come back as soon as I wasn't behind the wheel.    Making good on the promise, a few friends and I stopped by after skating on the embarcadero later that evening.  Luckily, our visit coincided with happy hour and live music (more on that later).  The place, true to its namesake, resides in a checkered red & white brick building sporting some nice signage out front.  As you walk in, a small, precarious staircase to your right leads to a loft containing tables and a TV--a good place to conquer if you're arriving with a big group and/or wanna watch the game.  Otherwise, as you venture further into the main floor you're greeted by a streetlamp, long main communal table sprouting a tree in its center, mahogany booths to your right and an mirror-backed bar on your left.  The walls variously host wallpaper, an assortment of interesting pictures/people, and the question-of-the-day chalkboard.  The latter offers menu discounts for answers to somewhat off-kilter questions.    The happy hour menu was very respectable---notably the $10 beer pitchers.  And while it's difficult to get your entree under the same price, the atmosphere and craftsmanship, particularly with the sandwiches, warrants the cost.   On our trip, a talented bassist and guitar player were running through holiday standards.  Would've been enough to give even the wet bandits pause.    Screw catch and release---this one's a keeper.

q29DsL5xmpdV42bJ6XLkBg.review_text: Food is definitely drool-icious, but food does come out slow.  The first time we came here it was late, so our food came quick and we had the bar food. The second time I came here, it wasn't really busy, but it was dinner time and we waited for 20+ minutes for our food to come. But I've had the Chicken Pot pie here and it was soOoo good especially after a cold Giants game.  I've also had their burger which was definitely delish. I will still come here even though wait time isn't the greatest, but food eventually is worth the wait.

bIExzobT8e__xY30lQ6oFg.review_text: I'm signing up on this website just to leave a review for Brickhouse Cafe. This place is tops. TOPS.

WwJDLOWlGQytGruRXg39MA.review_text: Really like this place - funky ambiance (kind of like a N'Orleans shotgun shack plopped down in SF), good beer selection, hearty comfort food.

btgZWY-IciTg4q61saeJ9Q.review_text: Probably the only reasonably priced ($10-14) sit-down restaurant in SOMA that has good food. Cute interior (it looks like a retrofitted home? since it has a staircase leading upstairs).

K0zrsXqu55JPwT4dnvNUDg.review_text: Before coming here, I already had a picture in my mind of what to get, poppers, calamari, and a stella.  So I came back here with Juliane N.  and just to add to the deal I encountered for their happy hour last time, I brought a Restaurant.com coupon for $25 off $45  Who knew it was so hard to meet the $45 mark.  Well, it became a challenge and in the end I had to order something for lunch today to hit it.   But nevertheless, I've got good lunch today and the food was good and cheap! The jalapeno poppers, omg, were so hot when they came out.  They might actually be store bought and just reheated, but it was still pretty good.  You can't go wrong with the Tidbits they serve here, and especially at Happy Hour when everything is about $1-2 off. The calamari also were good and always a staple food for happy hour it seems these days.   And the newest selection was the rigatoni with cheese (mac n cheese pretty much) except its rigatoni.  All really good and filling.

tcqi5sCJdmD-fVVuqUkJtQ.review_text: Nice place for dinner. We had the pot pie, Asian salad and tomato bisque soup...all were tasty. Will hopefully try this place out for lunch since it seems like they would be a good place for sandwiches/burgers. I would definitely recommend this place.

kUsBcitmM0_vY9uLba5VQg.review_text: Great burger!  I have been looking for a good burger since Q's burger has declined in quality.  And here it is.  They made it correctly which is a rarity these days - pink in the middle.  The atmosphere is great and the portions were definitely worth the price.  Looking forward to trying their other items on my next visit.

yi9eAPNgnqBGaRQ_Eyz2Aw.review_text: I came here during my lunch hour today and didn't have to wait very long to order. The staff is friendly and pretty much on it. My lunch order was the Pineapple Burger and an ice cold Stella on tap! :) My friend also ordered a Stella and hadn't realized I had grabbed hers at the same time as I picked up mine. So she went to the bar looking for her Stella, and wouldn't you know, the bar man gaver her another. I like that kind of customer service.   The burger was juicy and thick, swiss was nice and cheesy and the bread was pretty awesome too. The fries were great, firm and crunchy but not totally toasted. Kinda like McDonalds fries the way they used to be before they changed cooking oils. (old school style..yum!) Instead of Ketchup I like to have ranch with my fries. Their ranch, along with most of their dressings and sauces are all home made. I'm almost tempted to say it was one of the best ranch sauces I have ever had?! Pretty good!!!  Overall it was very good, and I would definitely return.

nO4bSABjYmR3MVvVjC0EeQ.review_text: Nice intimate brickhouse cafe.. even better is the mezzanine seating area that we were not allowed to use (understaffed on a weekday night maybe?)  I chose the place for the cozy decor and diverse.  Reviews of their sandwiches sounded great and I was craving a french dip.  Unfortunately, nothing my party of 4 ordered was very good.  Decent at best.. flavor was lacking in the burgers and french dip.  The fish and chips had freezer burn. And the service was okay but nothing to smile about.  At one point I gave up trying to flag down our waitress and walked up to the counter for horseradish.  I left rather embarased for choosing such a poor venue.  Luckily, for about $15 a person? no one left too upset.

Cth2m0XJ2wdPQwU__eF6GQ.review_text: There are only three things in life that I would kill for:  1. The chance to lick Jessica Alba's forearm.  2. The chance to make sweet love to Jessica Alba's forearm.  3. Good coffee.  I know the first two doesn't make sense, but you'll soon understand once you see me on the cover of the September issue of Forearm Fetish.  Anyway, good coffee is a must-have for me. I drink my coffee black so I can savor each drop uninterrupted by sugar or milk or half and half or the loose change passersby continue to drop into my cup when I'm huddled under the bus stop bench trying to enjoy my cup o' joe.  When my coworkers brought me to Brickhouse Cafe & Bar, I ordered a Red Eye, my favorite drink when I'm hungover, horny, or trying to get by on two hours of sleep.  Let's just say that the Red Eye they served was the best fucking coffee I've ever tasted in my life. Ever.   I'd fly out to San Francisco every day if I had the money just to drink their coffee.  In retrospect, I may have just been too hungover, too horny, and too tired from only two hours of sleep the night before that my taste buds were just fucking with me.  Either way, at the time, that shit was the shit!  Footnote: They also have an impressive full bar inside so that alone is five stars.

Zy1G15LwnSIn26PP_4uYgQ.review_text: Home of the big azz burger! Food is good! Happy hour menu is good except they don't have DOS EQUIS. This place packs in quick so the waitstaff may take a while.

mujiuKFSHUH969VzxQJonQ.review_text: I still love Brickhouse, but those brownies that I mentioned are no more, sadly. Now I love the fries and burgers. Seriously, they are the best in the city. So, now, this is a place where you come for a beer and burger.

kCQRWc_C4F8pgQE_yVp1KQ.review_text: Nice ambiance, friendly and attentive service, excellent food

so7fuRfRaGCpsZ6X1rfvyg.review_text: While the food is pretty good, the value isn't quite there. Average burger is about $12 and you get potato chips, not fries.   I work in the area, so it's very convenient, but not sure I'd go out of my way to eat here.

n-kTF1-narG_brOPZJPQAQ.review_text: Nice ingredients, tons of choice, weak grill master.  It pisses me off when you go to a $12 burger place and they can't cook the meat right.  I mean, what else is there to making a burger?  That's the one thing you have to do other than take the bun out of the plastic bag.  I ordered medium, got well done.  My friend ordered medium rare, got well done.  That is just lazy.

0O6gxh3ei_B4gv_qGlUrvg.review_text: This is a great local gastro-pub type restaurant.  It has, as others have said, an eclectic western ranch type decor that is relaxing and homey.  We live around the corner from this place and it gets SUPER packed on Giants game days.   We find, that you just have to know the schedule of the games and come slightly later or earlier, depending. We have noticed, that on game days, if you end up there when the people show up, it tends to be less locals and more (slightly ruder) game goers.  Sorry guys, its true.  Their big-ass burger is really great.  We have also had several of the other dishes and all of it is good and a decent value.  The fish and chips were good and we had a big salad one night and loved that too.  Staff is very friendly and the noise level isn't too bad, so it allows you to have a conversation while you eat.  We go here a lot and are happy to have a place like this so close to home.  Thanks guys for being there for the locals!

Lb37hatAjI3fgHEh2lMNEw.review_text: When I moved to SOMA I had two options: - Hire some movers and pay them to maybe make off with some of my stuff without me realizing it. This would also imply paying some $200+ to DPT to block off the street parking next to my new apartment for a couple hours. - Hire a Ryder truck in San Jose, circle the bay to pick up stuff from my girlfriend's place in Oakland, pack it all in, get someone to feed the meter while watching out for DPT, and then bribe my friends with Extreme Pizza and dinner at the Brickhouse on me as recompense. Way more fun!!  Good beer .. good burgers.. good fish and chips.. and good brunch (with mimosas!) It's my local burger joint now. They have a lot of stuff on their menu and good daily specials!  So it's rated 3.5 stars right now.. Really? It's true, I can't justify giving it 5, but I think it deserves a solid 4 overall.

OBA9tU7xH0Mx8R_8P7bOKg.review_text: I like the homey feel with the wooden interior and private booths. The staff is always upbeat and the menu selection is awesome. I have yet to order something that is not solid. The chicken brie sandwich is my go-to but everything I've tried here has been good. Sandwiches come with a salad but I always sub rings, since I like the way they make them here.   I've only been here for lunch, but it seems like a cool place to grab a drink after work. One day.

VX63D1pxxwd9vaxbqd_wDQ.review_text: Great food!  Every dish I've had there has been delicious! (huevos rancheros, yellowtail sandwich, kale salad, and bread pudding)

-hXelY09pOhXGJr4WuyvUQ.review_text: Fried Polenta is delicious here! Perfect crisp on the outside and moist on the inside. Served with a tomato sauce that isn't overpowering.  LOVED.  And this place is great for private parties -- they have a 2nd floor as well so basically 2 bars. The people working here, in kitchen and at bar, are all so friendly as well.  Oh the pineapple/rum/rosemary or sage cocktail is delicious too.  Can't wait to come back.

MQMR1dX63QMNxFu4KrkOMQ.review_text: This is the Brickhouse Cafe & Bar on Brannan Street and it has made its way into my "Food Hall of Fame"!  They have everything from burgers to lattes!  Brickhouse has the "Big Ass Burger" and they even have the "Smaller Ass Burger" for the health wise diner as well as a number of other mouthwatering delectables.  The salads will knock your socks off too.  All of their sauces, be it either BBQ or salad dressing, are made in-house and are simply delicious.  The wait isn't very long, but if you wanna eat in, get there a little before the lunch rush.    The burgers are fresh and juicy and the salads are delightfully crisp and refreshing.  If you're feeling parched, you may also opt to indulge in a draft beer or a tasty pick-me-up!  On my recent visit, I had the Turkey Cesar Sandwich on foccacia!  The romaine was crisp, the croutons weren't soggy and over dressed and the turkey was nice and moist.     The price range here is very reasonable.  The entrees range from $7 - $15...the high end menu item is the 'Wagu' Kobe Beef burger!  That will be on my next venture to the Brickhouse.  So, if you are looking for something other than last night's leftovers, which, I'm sure, are tasty, check out the Brickhouse Café and Bar.  Bon Appetit!

-Hxvjz-t5ttsuH6H1osA4A.review_text: After exhausting our list of Sunday brunch locale choices, we ended up here after calling and being told there was no wait (11:30am)  Food was definitely stuff I could make on my own. It was decent, but not something I'd return for; 2.5-3 stars.  SERVICE: the staff was pretty friendly, but our waiter was a bit of a spacehead. The busboy was nice and never let my water glass go empty.  AMBIANCE: I liked the overall feel of the space, except for the awkward tree growing out of the table. That was weird (and dirty! SOO dusty... I was afraid it was going to get into my food)  FOOD: - Carlito's Fritata: much smaller and denser than I imagined. I thought I'd be getting a nice fluffy fritata... instead it was like an omelette that hadn't been folded over. Plus it was so weirdly cooked-- rubbery in some spots and totally runny in others (ew).  - Western Cowboy scramble: I only tried a few bites of this. It was mediocre.
